quoteFirst: The crew of the _Dodge_, consisting of twenty-two persons, made a considerable addition to our small community. We fired the prize at
quoteLast: , P. M., as the shades of evening were closing in, and made sail on our course. The flames burned red and lurid in the murky atmosphere, like some Jack-o'-lantern; now appearing, and now disappearing, as the doomed ship rose upon the top, or descended into the abyss of the waves.
title: Memoirs of Service Afloat, During the War Between the States
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877

quoteFirst: [219] A little above this river, on the opposite shore, is a Roman church, at a settlement known by the name of Point Coupée, which signifies a point cut off.[220] At half past three we proceeded with difficulty, owing to high winds, and getting a little alarmed we made shore.
quoteLast: , P. M. we came to the head of two islands both of which stood athwart our way; they are the more remarkable being the last in the Mississippi, except below New Orleans. Between these islands the navigation is dangerous, but a safe and good passage for boats or vessels of any burden may be had on either side.
title: Cuming's tour to the western country (1807-1809)
author: Cuming, Fortescue, 1762-1828; Thwaites, Reuben Gold, 1853-1913 [Editor]

title: Weatherby's Inning: A Story of College Life and Baseball

quoteLast: , having passed the night comfortably with pleasant dreams, is this occasioned by an empty stomach? Found we had made little way during the night; said to the second mate that we had got on very quickly, but he said they had had a busy time of it, as the wind had been in almost every point.
title: A Journey to America in 1834
author: Heywood, Robert, 1786-1868

quoteLast: to awaken us. The old nun who was acting as night-watch immediately spoke aloud:

quoteLast: passed out of the harbour of Fort Royal, or rather now Fort de France. The pilot repeated the intelligence that there was a frigate off the Diamond Rock.

quoteFirst: The tide had risen enough by
quoteLast: for the water to lick the sides of the boat, but it would be a full hour or more before the _Aphrodite_ would float up out of the mud, and even then it would be necessary to wait awhile longer for deeper water, before trying to push her great bulk through the rank marsh grass.

quoteFirst: _Friday, February 2nd_.--I was called at five o'clock, and at
quoteLast: Mabelle and I started for the market. It was blowing a gale, and our four oarsmen found it as much as they could do to reach the shore. The Shanghai mail-boat was just in, and I pitied the poor passengers, who were in all the misery of being turned out into the cold of the early morning, with the spray breaking over them as they sat in the small boats.
title: A Voyage in the 'Sunbeam', Our Home on the Ocean for Eleven Months
author: Brassey, Annie, 1839-1887

quoteFirst: I knelt by his bed side, and with my hand upon his pale forehead asked my Heavenly Father to forgive my sins, and that the sufferings of my companion might cease, and if he was appointed unto death, and could not remain with us, that he might be quickly eased from pain and fall asleep in peace. Almost immediately all pain left him, and in a short time he sweetly fell asleep in death, without a struggle or a groan, at
quoteLast: on the morning of the 11th of January, 1847. His remains were interred at sun-set on the evening of the day he died.
title:
Scraps of Biography
Tenth Book of the Faith-Promoting Series. Designed for the Instruction and Encouragement of Young Latter-day Saints

quoteLast: , remaining at table until eight. The Englishman, later in all his hours, and more ponderous in all his habits, sits down to table about the time the Frenchman gets up; quitting it between nine and ten. The Italian pays a tribute to his climate, and has his early dinner and light supper, both usually alone, the habits of the country carrying him to the opera and the _conversazione_ for social communion.
title: Satanstoe; Or, the Littlepage Manuscripts. A Tale of the Colony
author: Cooper, James Fenimore, 1789-1851

quoteFirst: People were speaking about the Haymarket meeting in the car. I didn’t tell them I knew anything about it. I think I got home about
quoteLast: . I had no conversation with the landlady. After my supper, my impression is I went to Mr. Roe’s house. He was not at home. I stayed there about fifteen minutes talking with Mrs. Roe.
